<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="left">
<A name="101"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt">PART I &#151; FINANCIAL INFORMATION
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="102"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt">Item&nbsp;1. Financial Statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="103"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Kraft Foods Inc. and Subsidiaries<BR>
Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets<BR>
(in millions of dollars)<BR>
(Unaudited)

</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head --><TR valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="106"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt">Kraft Foods Inc. and Subsidiaries<BR>
Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows<BR>
(in millions of dollars)<BR>
(Unaudited)
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head --><TR valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="70">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="6"><B>For the Three Months Ended</B></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->6<!-- /Folio -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify">
<A name="107"></A>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt">Kraft Foods Inc. and Subsidiaries<BR>
Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
(Unaudited)
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Note 1. Accounting Policies:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Basis of Presentation:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The interim condensed consolidated financial statements of Kraft Foods Inc. (&#147;Kraft&#148;), together
with its subsidiaries (collectively referred to as the &#147;Company&#148;), are unaudited. It is the opinion
of the Company&#146;s management that all adjustments necessary for a fair statement of the interim
results presented have been reflected therein. All such adjustments were of a normal recurring
nature. Net revenues and net earnings for any interim period are not necessarily indicative of
results that may be expected for the entire year.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">These statements should be read in conjunction with the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements
and related notes, which are included in the Company&#146;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;31, 2007, the Altria Group, Inc. (&#147;Altria&#148;) Board of Directors announced that Altria
would spin off all of its remaining interest (89.0%) in the Company on a pro rata basis to Altria
stockholders in a tax-free transaction. Effective as of the close of business on March&nbsp;30, 2007,
the separation of Kraft from Altria and the distribution of all Kraft
shares owned by Altria to
Altria&#146;s stockholders was completed (the &#147;Distribution&#148;). The Distribution ratio was calculated by
dividing the number of Class&nbsp;A common shares of Kraft held by Altria by the number of Altria shares
outstanding on the date of record, March&nbsp;16, 2007. Based on the number of Altria shares
outstanding on the date of record, the distribution ratio was 0.692024 shares of Kraft Class&nbsp;A
common stock for every share of Altria common stock outstanding. Prior to the Distribution, Altria
converted its Class&nbsp;B shares of Kraft common stock, which carried ten votes per share, into Class&nbsp;A
shares of Kraft, which carry one vote per share. Following the Distribution, only Class&nbsp;A common
shares of Kraft are outstanding and Altria does not own any shares of Kraft.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Accounting Pronouncement:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&nbsp;157,
<I>Fair Value Measurements</I>, which will be effective for financial statements issued for fiscal years
beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2007. This statement defines fair value, establishes a framework for
measuring fair value and expands disclosures about fair value measurements. The adoption of this
statement is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&#146;s financial statements.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Reclassification:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Classification of certain prior year statement of earnings amounts related to minority interest in
earnings have been reclassified into general corporate expenses to conform with the current year&#146;s
presentation within marketing, administration and research costs.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><U><B>Note
2. Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Restructuring Program:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In January&nbsp;2004, the Company announced a three-year restructuring program with the objectives of
leveraging the Company&#146;s global scale, realigning and lowering its cost structure, and optimizing
capacity utilization. In January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring
efforts through 2008. The entire restructuring program is expected to result in $3.0&nbsp;billion in
pre-tax charges reflecting asset disposals, severance and implementation costs. As part of this
program, the Company anticipates the closure of up to 40 facilities and the elimination of
approximately 14,000 positions. Approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion of the $3.0&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges
are expected to require cash payments. Pre-tax restructuring program charges during 2007 are
expected to be approximately $625&nbsp;million, including $88&nbsp;million incurred in the first quarter of
2007. Total pre-tax restructuring charges incurred since the inception of the program in January
2004 were $1.7&nbsp;billion.</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->7<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the second quarter of 2006, the Company announced a seven-year, $1.7&nbsp;billion agreement to
receive information technology services from Electronic Data Systems (&#147;EDS&#148;). The agreement, which
includes data centers, web hosting, telecommunications and IT workplace services, began on June&nbsp;1,
2006. The Company reversed pre-tax restructuring costs of $7&nbsp;million due to lower than anticipated
severance costs and incurred implementation costs of $15&nbsp;million related to the transition for the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007. These amounts were included in the pre-tax restructuring
program charges discussed above.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Restructuring Costs:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2007 and 2006, pre-tax charges under the restructuring program of $67
million and $92&nbsp;million, respectively, were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the
condensed consolidated statements of earnings. The first quarter 2007 pre-tax charges resulted
from costs relating to renegotiation of supplier contracts, and the continuation of workforce
reduction programs associated with the previously announced closing of 27 plants since January
2004. No plants were closed in the first quarter of 2007. Approximately $54&nbsp;million of the first
quarter 2007 pre-tax charges will require cash payments.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Pre-tax restructuring liability activity for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 was as follows:</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Severance costs in the above schedule, which relate to the workforce reduction programs, include
the cost of related benefits. Specific programs announced since 2004, as part of the overall
restructuring program, will result in the elimination of approximately 9,800 positions. At March
31, 2007, approximately 9,000 of these positions have been eliminated. Asset write-downs relate to
the impairment of assets caused by the plant closings and related activity. Other costs incurred
relate primarily to renegotiation of supplier contracts, the continuation of workforce reduction
programs associated with the plant closings and the termination of leasing agreements. Severance
costs taken against assets relate to incremental pension costs, which reduce prepaid pension
assets.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Implementation Costs:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company recorded pre-tax implementation costs of $21&nbsp;million in the first quarter associated
with the restructuring program. These costs include incremental costs related to the closure of
facilities and costs related to the EDS transition discussed above. Substantially all
implementation costs incurred in 2007 will require cash payments. These costs were recorded on the
condensed consolidated statements of earnings as follows:</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->8<!-- /Folio -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Asset Impairment Charges:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2007, the Company sold its hot cereal assets and trademarks for a
pre-tax gain of $12&nbsp;million. The Company incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $69&nbsp;million
in the fourth quarter of 2006 in recognition of the sale. The charge, which included the write-off
of a portion of the associated goodwill, and intangible and fixed assets, was recorded as asset
impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. During the third quarter of
2006, the Company sold its pet snacks brand and assets and recorded tax expense of $57&nbsp;million
related to the sale. In addition, the Company incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86
million in the first quarter of 2006 in recognition of the sale. The charge, which included the
write-off of a portion of the associated goodwill and intangible and fixed assets, was recorded as
asset impairment and exit costs on the condensed consolidated statement of earnings.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2007, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and
intangible assets and no charges resulted from this review. During the first quarter of 2006, the
Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and recorded non-cash pre-tax
charges of $24&nbsp;million related to an intangible asset impairment for biscuits assets in Egypt and
hot cereal assets in the United States. These charges were recorded as asset impairment and exit
costs on the condensed consolidated statement of earnings.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Total:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The pre-tax asset impairment, exit and implementation costs discussed above, for the three months
ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 and March&nbsp;31, 2006, were included in the segment operating income of the
following segments:</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->9<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">





<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Note
3. Related Party Transactions:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Through the first quarter of 2007, Altria&#146;s subsidiary, Altria Corporate Services, Inc. (&#147;ALCS&#148;),
provided the Company with various services, including planning, legal, treasury, auditing,
insurance, human resources, office of the secretary, corporate affairs, information technology,
aviation and tax services. Billings for these services, which were based on the cost to ALCS to
provide such services and a 5% management fee based on wages and benefits, were $19&nbsp;million and $52
million for the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;30, 2007, Kraft entered into a Transition Services Agreement (the &#147;Transition Services
Agreement&#148;) with ALCS pursuant to which ALCS will provide select administrative services to Kraft
during 2007 to ensure continuity of activity following the Distribution. These services primarily
relate to information technology in anticipation of the transition to EDS.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;30, 2007, Kraft entered into an Employee Matters Agreement (the &#147;Employee Matters
Agreement&#148;) with Altria. The Employee Matters Agreement provides for each company&#146;s respective
obligations with regard to employee transfers, equity compensation and other employee benefits
matters.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;30, 2007, Kraft entered into a Tax Sharing Agreement (the &#147;Tax Sharing Agreement&#148;) with
Altria. The Tax Sharing Agreement generally governs Altria&#146;s and Kraft&#146;s respective rights,
responsibilities and obligations after the Distribution with respect to taxes attributable to
Kraft&#146;s business, as well as any taxes incurred by Altria or Kraft as a result of the failure of
the Distribution to qualify for tax-free treatment under Section&nbsp;355 of the Internal Revenue Code
of 1986, as amended.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">At March&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group, Inc. of
$449&nbsp;million and $472&nbsp;million, respectively. The amounts payable to Altria generally include
accrued dividends, taxes and service fees. As discussed in Note 6. <I>Stock Plans</I>, the Company
reimbursed Altria $179&nbsp;million for net settlement of employee stock awards. As further discussed
in Note 13. <I>Income Taxes</I>, the Company&#146;s federal income taxes payable and federal income tax
contingencies were previously recorded as liabilities on the balance sheet of Altria. Upon the
Distribution, Altria reimbursed the Company $304&nbsp;million for these liabilities, comprising
approximately $375&nbsp;million in contingencies for uncertain tax positions, plus interest before taxes
of $77&nbsp;million, and less $148&nbsp;million of taxes payable at March&nbsp;30, 2007. Interest on intercompany
borrowings is based on the applicable London Interbank Offered Rate. All intercompany accounts
were settled within 30&nbsp;days of the Distribution date of March&nbsp;30, 2007.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The
net amount payable to Altria at March&nbsp;31, 2007 was as follows:</DIV>

<DIV align="right">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="94%">
<!-- Begin Table Head --><TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="48%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="40%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Accrued dividends</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">364</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Intercompany cash balances</DIV></TD>

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter 2007, the Company purchased 1.4&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;A common stock at
an aggregate cost of $46.5&nbsp;million from Altria per the provisions of the Distribution agreement.
The aggregate cash amount paid by Kraft was based on a per share price of $32.085, which was
calculated as the average of the high and the low price of Kraft&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock on March&nbsp;1,
2007.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also, see Note 13. <I>Income Taxes </I>regarding the impact to the Company of the closure of an Internal
Revenue Service review of Altria&#146;s consolidated federal income tax return recorded during the first
quarter of 2006.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->10<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">



<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Note 4. Acquisition:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the Company acquired the Spanish and Portuguese operations of United Biscuits
(&#147;UB&#148;) and rights to all Nabisco trademarks in the European Union, Eastern Europe, the Middle East
and Africa, which UB has held since 2000, for a total cost of approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion. For the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007, these businesses contributed net revenues of approximately $97
million.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><U><B>Note 5. Divestitures:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2007, the Company sold its hot cereal assets and trademarks. The
aggregate proceeds received from this sale were $200&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded a
pre-tax gain of $12&nbsp;million.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the third quarter of 2006 the Company sold its pet snacks brand and assets. The Company
incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2006 in
recognition of this sale.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The operating results of the divestitures discussed above, in the aggregate, were not material to
the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in any of the
periods presented.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><U><B>Note 6. Stock Plans:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">At Distribution, as described in Note 1. <I>Accounting Policies</I>, Altria stock awards were modified
through the issuance of Kraft stock awards, and accordingly the stock awards were split into two
instruments. Holders of Altria stock options received a new Kraft option to acquire shares of
Kraft common stock and an adjusted Altria option for the same number of shares of Altria common
stock with a reduced exercise price. For each employee stock option outstanding, the aggregate
intrinsic value of the option immediately prior to the Distribution was not greater than the
aggregate intrinsic value of the option immediately after the Distribution. Holders of Altria
restricted stock or stock rights awarded prior to January&nbsp;31, 2007, retained their existing awards
and received restricted stock or stock rights in Kraft common stock. Recipients of Altria stock
rights awarded on or after January&nbsp;31, 2007, did not receive restricted stock or stock rights of
Kraft.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Based upon the number of Altria stock awards outstanding at the date of Distribution, the Company
issued stock options for approximately 24&nbsp;million shares of Kraft common stock expiring between
2007 and 2012 at a weighted-average price of $15.75. In addition, the Company issued approximately
3.0&nbsp;million shares of restricted stock and stock rights, with a market value per restricted share
or right of $31.66 on the date of grant. Restrictions on the majority of the stock and rights
granted lapse in either the first quarter of 2008 or 2009.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As outlined in Note 3. <I>Related Party Transactions</I>, the Company reimbursed Altria $179&nbsp;million for
net settlement of employee stock awards. Altria reimbursed the Company $240&nbsp;million for the
fair value, using the Black-Scholes option valuation model, of the Kraft stock options received by Altria employees. The Company
reimbursed Altria $440&nbsp;million for the fair value, using the
Black-Scholes option valuation model, of the Altria stock options
received by Kraft employees. Altria paid $33&nbsp;million to the Company for the fair value of the
Kraft restricted stock or stock rights received by holders of Altria restricted stock or stock
rights less the value of projected forfeitures. The Company paid $12&nbsp;million to Altria for the
fair value of restricted stock or stock rights received by holders of Kraft restricted stock or
stock rights less the value of projected forfeitures.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The total intrinsic value of Kraft stock options exercised during the three months ended March&nbsp;31,
2007 was $3.3&nbsp;million. No stock options were exercised during the three months ended March&nbsp;31,
2006.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In January&nbsp;2007, the Company issued approximately 5.2&nbsp;million shares of restricted stock and stock
rights to eligible U.S. and non-U.S. employees. Restrictions on these shares and rights lapse in
the first quarter of 2010. The market value per restricted share or right was $34.655 on the date
of grant. The total number of restricted shares and rights issued in the first quarter of 2007 was
8.2&nbsp;million, including those issued as a result of the Distribution.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first quarter of 2007, approximately 4.3&nbsp;million shares of restricted stock and stock rights
vested at a market value of $144&nbsp;million. The grant date fair value per share was $32.23.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->11<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

options that were excluded from the
calculation of weighted average shares for diluted EPS, because their effects were antidilutive,
was immaterial. The stock options and stock rights issued on the date of the Distribution did not have a significant effect on the number of
the weighted average shares for diluted EPS. For the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, all of the
Class&nbsp;A common stock options were excluded from the calculation of weighted average shares for
diluted EPS because their effects were antidilutive.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><U><B>Note 8. Contingencies:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Kraft and its subsidiaries are parties to a variety of legal proceedings arising out of the normal
course of business, including a few cases in which substantial amounts of damages are sought. While
the results of litigation cannot be predicted with certainty, management believes that the final
outcome of these proceedings will not have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated
financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Third-Party Guarantees: </I>At March&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company&#146;s third-party guarantees, which are
primarily derived from acquisition, divestiture and construction activities, were approximately $25
million, of which approximately $8&nbsp;million have no specified expiration dates. Substantially all of
the remainder expire through 2016, with $1&nbsp;million expiring by March&nbsp;31, 2008. The Company is
required to perform under these guarantees in the event that a third party fails to make
contractual payments or achieve performance measures. The Company has a liability of $19&nbsp;million on
its condensed consolidated balance sheet at March&nbsp;31, 2007, relating to these guarantees.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->12<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Non-amortizable intangible assets consist substantially of brand names purchased through the
Nabisco and UB acquisitions. Amortizable intangible assets consist primarily of certain trademark
licenses and non-compete agreements. During the quarter, the Company reclassified $80&nbsp;million from
non-amortizable to amortizable intangible assets as part of the UB acquisition, wrote off a fully
amortized intangible asset for $18&nbsp;million, and adjusted goodwill by $85&nbsp;million upon the adoption
of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (see Note 13. <I>Income Taxes</I>, for further details). Amortization
expense for intangible assets was $2&nbsp;million for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006.
Amortization expense for each of the next five years is currently estimated to be approximately $10
million or less.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The movement in goodwill and gross carrying amount of intangible assets from December&nbsp;31, 2006, is
as follows:</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><U><B>Note 10. Segment Reporting:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company manufactures and markets packaged food products, consisting principally of beverages,
cheese, snacks, convenient meals and various packaged grocery products. Kraft manages and reports
operating results through two commercial units, Kraft North America and Kraft International.
Reportable segments for Kraft North America are organized and managed principally by product
category. Kraft North America&#146;s segments are North America Beverages; North America Cheese &#038;
Foodservice; North America Convenient Meals; North America Grocery; and North America Snacks &#038;
Cereals. Kraft International&#146;s operations are organized and managed by geographic location. Kraft
International&#146;s segments are European Union and Developing Markets (this segment was formerly
called Developing Markets, Oceania &#038; North Asia).</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->13<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s management uses segment operating income to evaluate segment performance and allocate
resources. Operating income for the reportable segments excludes unallocated general corporate
expenses and amortization of intangibles. Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this
measure to help investors analyze the business performance and trends of the various business
segments. Interest and other debt expense, net, and provision for income taxes are centrally
managed and, accordingly, such items are not presented by segment because they are not included in
the measure of segment profitability reviewed by management. The Company&#146;s assets, which are
principally in the United States and Europe, are managed geographically.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Segment data were as follows:</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As discussed in Note 2. <I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs</I>, the Company recorded asset
impairment, exit and implementation costs of $88&nbsp;million and $215&nbsp;million during the first quarter
of 2007 and 2006, respectively.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2007, the Company sold its hot cereal assets and trademarks and
recorded a pre-tax gain of $12&nbsp;million. This gain is included in the segment operating income of
the North America Snacks &#038; Cereals segment.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->14<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2006, the Company sold a small U.S. biscuit brand, resulting in a
pre-tax loss of $2&nbsp;million. This loss is included in the segment operating income of the North
America Snacks &#038; Cereals segment. In addition, the Company sold certain Canadian assets and
recorded a pre-tax loss of $1&nbsp;million. This loss is included in the segment operating income of
the North America Grocery segment.</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><U><B>Note 11. Financial Instruments:</B></U>
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, ineffectiveness related to cash flow hedges was
not material. At March&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company hedged forecasted commodity and foreign currency
transactions for periods not exceeding the next 21 and 57&nbsp;months, respectively. During the first
quarter of 2007, the Company began hedging currency exposure resulting from future cash flows
associated with new intercompany loans with foreign affiliates.</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Hedging activities affected accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses), net of income taxes,
as follows:</DIV>

<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="91%">

<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:60px; text-indent:-15px">&nbsp;</DIV></TD>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->15<!-- /Folio -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Note 12. Benefit Plans:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company sponsors noncontributory defined benefit pension plans covering substantially all U.S.
employees. Pension coverage for employees of the Company&#146;s non-U.S. subsidiaries is provided, to
the extent deemed appropriate, through separate plans, many of which are governed by local
statutory requirements. In addition, the Company&#146;s U.S. and Canadian subsidiaries provide health
care and other benefits to substantially all retired employees. Health care benefits for retirees
outside the United States and Canada are generally covered through local government plans.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Pension Plans:</I>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Employer Contributions</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company presently makes, and plans to make, contributions, to the extent that they are tax
deductible and do not generate an excise tax liability, to its U.S. and non-U.S. plans. During the
first quarter of 2007, $5&nbsp;million and $40&nbsp;million of employer contributions were made to U.S. plans
and non-U.S. plans, respectively. Currently, the Company anticipates making additional
contributions of approximately $11&nbsp;million during the remainder of 2007 to its U.S. plans and
approximately $117&nbsp;million during the remainder of 2007 to its non-U.S. plans. However, these
estimates are subject to change as a result of many factors, including changes in tax and other
benefit laws, as well as asset performance significantly above or below the assumed long-term rate
of return on pension assets, or significant changes in interest rates. During the first quarter of
2006, $130&nbsp;million and $25&nbsp;million of employer contributions were made to U.S. plans and non-U.S.
plans, respectively.</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Note 13. Income Taxes:</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company accounts for income taxes in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;109, <I>Accounting for Income Taxes</I>.
The U.S. accounts of the Company were included in the consolidated federal income tax return of
Altria. Income taxes were generally computed on a separate company basis. To the extent that
foreign tax credits, capital losses and other credits generated by the Company, which could not be
utilized on a separate company basis, were utilized in Altria&#146;s consolidated federal income tax
return, the benefit was recognized in the calculation of the Company&#146;s provision for income taxes.
The Company made payments to, or was reimbursed by, Altria for the tax effects resulting from its
inclusion in Altria&#146;s consolidated federal income tax return, including current taxes payable and
net changes in tax provisions. Beginning March&nbsp;31, 2007, Kraft is no longer a member of the Altria
consolidated tax return group and Kraft will file its own federal consolidated income tax return.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Prior to the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2007, federal tax contingencies relating to Kraft were carried
on the Altria balance sheet and reported in the Altria financial statements. Due to the spin-off
at March&nbsp;30, 2007, federal tax contingencies relating to Kraft were transferred from Altria to
Kraft during the first quarter and totaled $375&nbsp;million. There were no material changes during the
quarter due to settlements with tax authorities or due to the expiration of the statute of
limitations. Kraft recognizes accrued interest and penalties associated with uncertain tax
positions as part of the tax provision. As of January&nbsp;1, 2007, Kraft had $125&nbsp;million of accrued
interest and penalties. The change to accrued interest and penalties during the first quarter was
not significant.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, <I>Accounting for the Uncertainty in Income
Taxes &#151; an interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109</I>, (&#147;FIN 48&#148;) which became effective for the
Company on January&nbsp;1, 2007. FIN 48 prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement criteria for
the financial statement recognition and measurement of tax positions taken or expected to be taken
in a tax return. For those benefits to be recognized, a tax position must be more-likely-than-not
to be sustained upon examination by taxing authorities. The amount recognized is measured as the
largest amount of benefit that is greater than 50&nbsp;percent likely of being realized upon ultimate
settlement. Prior to the implementation of FIN 48, the Company established additional provisions
for income taxes when, despite the belief that existing tax positions were fully supportable, there
remained certain positions that were likely to be challenged and that may not have been sustained
on review by tax authorities. The adoption of FIN 48 resulted in an increase to shareholders&#146;
equity as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 of $213&nbsp;million. This increase to shareholders&#146; equity resulted in a
$265&nbsp;million decrease in the liability for unrecognized tax benefits, comprised of $247&nbsp;million in
tax and $18&nbsp;million in interest, a reduction in goodwill of $85&nbsp;million, and an increase to federal
and state deferred tax assets of $33&nbsp;million.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As of January&nbsp;1, 2007, after the implementation of FIN 48, Kraft&#146;s unrecognized tax benefits were
$667&nbsp;million. If all of these benefits were recognized, the net impact on the effective tax rate
would be $530&nbsp;million. It is expected that the amount of unrecognized tax benefits will increase
in the next twelve months in an estimated range of $65-$80&nbsp;million from a variety of federal, state
and foreign uncertain tax positions. The change to Kraft&#146;s unrecognized tax benefits was not
significant to the quarter.</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company is regularly audited by federal, state and foreign tax authorities, and these audits
are at various stages at any given time. In the first quarter of 2006, the United States Internal
Revenue Service (&#147;IRS&#148;) concluded its examination of Altria&#146;s consolidated federal income tax
returns for the years 1996 through 1999 that included Kraft. Consequently, Altria reimbursed the
Company in cash for unrequired federal tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million and pre-tax interest of $46
million ($29&nbsp;million after-tax). The Company also recognized net state tax reversals of $39
million, resulting in a total net earnings benefit of $405&nbsp;million or $0.24 per diluted share, in
the first quarter of 2006. The U.S. federal statute of limitations remains open for the year 2000
and onward with years 2000 to 2003 currently under examination by the IRS. Foreign and U.S. state
jurisdictions have statutes of limitations generally ranging from 3 to 5&nbsp;years. Years still open to
examination by foreign tax authorities in major jurisdictions include Germany (1999 onward), Brazil
(2001 onward), Canada (2001 onward) and Spain (2001 onward). The Company is currently under
examination by taxing authorities in various U.S. state and foreign jurisdictions.</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->17<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify">
<A name="108"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head --><TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="70%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><DIV style="margin-left:0px; text-indent:-0px">Item&nbsp;2.
</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="top"><B>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body --></TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Description of the Company</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Kraft Foods Inc. (&#147;Kraft&#148;), together with its subsidiaries (collectively referred to as the
&#147;Company&#148;), manufactures and markets packaged food products, consisting principally of beverages,
cheese, snacks, convenient meals and various packaged grocery products. Kraft manages and reports
operating results through two commercial units, Kraft North America and Kraft International.
Reportable segments for Kraft North America are organized and managed principally by product
category. Kraft International&#146;s operations are organized and managed by geographic location.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;31, 2007, the Altria Group, Inc. (&#147;Altria&#148;) Board of Directors announced that Altria
would spin off all of its remaining interest (89.0%) in the Company on a pro rata basis to Altria
stockholders in a tax-free transaction. Effective as of the close of business on March&nbsp;30, 2007,
the separation of Kraft from Altria and the distribution of all Kraft
shares owned by Altria to
Altria&#146;s stockholders was completed (the &#147;Distribution&#148;). The Distribution ratio was calculated by
dividing the number of Class&nbsp;A common shares of Kraft held by Altria by the number of Altria shares
outstanding on the date of record, March&nbsp;16, 2007. Based on the number of Altria shares
outstanding on the date of record, the distribution ratio was 0.692024 shares of Kraft Class&nbsp;A
common stock for every share of Altria common stock outstanding. Prior to the Distribution, Altria
converted its Class&nbsp;B shares of Kraft common stock, which carry ten votes per share, into Class&nbsp;A
shares of Kraft, which carry one vote per share. Following the Distribution, only Class&nbsp;A common
shares of Kraft are outstanding and Altria does not own any shares of Kraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Executive Summary</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The following executive summary is intended to provide significant highlights of the Discussion and
Analysis that follows.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Consolidated Operating Results for the Quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 </I><FONT style="font-family: Symbol">&#045;</FONT> The changes in the
Company&#146;s net earnings and diluted earnings per share (&#147;EPS&#148;) for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2007
from the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 were due primarily to the following (in millions, except per
share data):
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The favorable net impact of asset impairment, exit and implementation costs on earnings and diluted
EPS is due primarily to the following:
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Restructuring
Program </I>&#151; The Company announced a three-year restructuring program in January
2004. In January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring efforts through
2008. During the first quarters of 2007 and 2006, the Company recorded pre-tax charges of $88
million ($56&nbsp;million after-tax) and $105&nbsp;million ($74&nbsp;million after-tax), respectively, for the
restructuring plan, including pre-tax implementation costs of $21&nbsp;million and $13&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Asset Impairment Charges </I>&#151; The Company incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86&nbsp;million
($63&nbsp;million after-tax) million in the first quarter of 2006 in anticipation of the sale of its pet
snacks brand and assets. The charge, which included the write-off of a portion of the associated
goodwill and intangible and fixed assets, was recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the
condensed consolidated statement of earnings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition, during the first quarter of 2007, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill
and intangible assets and no charges resulted from this review. During the first quarter of 2006,
the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and recorded non-cash
pre-tax charges of $24&nbsp;million ($15&nbsp;million after-tax) related to an intangible asset impairment
for biscuits assets in Egypt and hot cereal assets in the United States. These charges were
recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the condensed consolidated statement of earnings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>For further details on the restructuring program or asset impairment and implementation costs, see
Note 2 to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and the Business Environment section of
the following Discussion and Analysis.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Sales of Businesses </I>&#151;The sales of businesses had an unfavorable impact on earnings due primarily
to the $8&nbsp;million after-tax loss on the sale of the Company&#146;s hot cereal assets and trademarks in
the first quarter of 2007. This sale resulted in a pre-tax gain of $12&nbsp;million due to the
differing tax bases.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Income Tax Benefit </I>&#151; The 2006 tax benefit reflects a reimbursement from Altria in cash for
unrequired federal tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million and pre-tax interest of $46&nbsp;million ($29&nbsp;million
after-tax), as well as net state tax reversals of $39&nbsp;million, due to the conclusion of an audit of
Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s consolidated federal income tax returns for the years 1996 through 1999.
Income taxes also include a benefit of $19&nbsp;million in 2007 and $48&nbsp;million in 2006 from the
resolution of outstanding items in the Company&#146;s international operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Operations </I>&#151; The $38&nbsp;million decrease in results from operations was due primarily to the
following:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align:justify">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Lower income in North America Convenient Meals, reflecting unfavorable net costs,
partially offset by favorable volume/mix.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

partially offset by favorable volume/mix.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>For further details, see the Consolidated Operating Results and Operating Results by Business
Segment sections of the following Discussion and Analysis.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>2007 Forecasted Results </I>&#151; Guidance remains consistent from year-end, when the Company disclosed
diluted EPS guidance for 2007 at $1.50 to $1.55. Guidance includes $0.25 per share of charges from
the Company&#146;s restructuring program and other impairment charges. The Company currently forecasts
its 2007 effective income tax rate to average 35.5%. The factors described in the &#147;Risk Factors&#148;
section of the Company&#146;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 represent
continuing risks to these forecasts.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Discussion and Analysis</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><U><B>Business Environment</B></U>

</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company is subject to a number of challenges that may adversely affect its businesses. These
challenges, which are discussed below and under the &#147;Risk Factors&#148; section of the Company&#146;s Annual
Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, include:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; text-align:justify">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>fluctuations in commodity prices;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>movements of foreign currencies;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>competitive challenges in various products and markets, including price gaps with
competitor products and the increasing price-consciousness of consumers;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>a rising cost environment and the limited ability to increase prices;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>a trend toward increasing consolidation in the retail trade and consequent pricing
pressure and inventory reductions;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>a growing presence of discount retailers, primarily in Europe, with an emphasis on own-label products;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>changing consumer preferences, including diet trends;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>competitors with different profit objectives and less susceptibility to currency exchange rates; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>concerns and/or regulations regarding food safety, quality and health, including
genetically modified organisms, trans-fatty acids and obesity. Increased government
regulation of the food industry could result in increased costs to the Company.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the ordinary course of business, the Company is subject to many influences that can impact the
timing of sales to customers, including the timing of holidays and other annual or special events,
seasonality of certain products, significant weather conditions, timing of Company or customer
incentive programs and pricing actions, customer inventory programs, Company initiatives to improve
supply chain efficiency, financial condition of customers and general economic conditions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Fluctuations in commodity costs can lead to retail price volatility and intense price competition,
and can influence consumer and trade buying patterns. During the first quarter of 2007, the
Company&#146;s commodity costs on average have been higher than those incurred in the first quarter of
2006 (most notably higher coffee and packaging costs, partially offset by lower nut costs). For
the first quarter of 2007 the Company&#146;s commodity costs were approximately $100&nbsp;million higher than
the first quarter of 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Restructuring:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In January&nbsp;2004, the Company announced a three-year restructuring program (which is discussed
further in Note 2. <I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs</I>) with the objectives of
leveraging the Company&#146;s global scale, realigning and lowering its cost structure, and optimizing
capacity utilization. In January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring
efforts through 2008. The entire restructuring program is expected to result in $3.0&nbsp;billion in
pre-tax charges, the closure of up to 40 facilities, the elimination of approximately 14,000
positions and annualized cost savings at the completion of the program of approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion. Approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion of the $3.0&nbsp;billion in
pre-tax charges are expected to require cash payments. Pre-tax restructuring program charges
during 2007 are expected to be approximately $625&nbsp;million. Total pre-tax restructuring program
charges incurred in the first quarters of 2007 and 2006, were $88&nbsp;million and $105&nbsp;million,
respectively. Total pre-tax restructuring charges for the program incurred from January&nbsp;2004
through March&nbsp;31, 2007 were $1.7&nbsp;billion and specific programs announced will result in the
elimination of approximately 9,800 positions. Approximately 60% of the pre-tax charges are expected
to require cash payments.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->20<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition, the Company expects to incur approximately $550&nbsp;million in capital expenditures to
implement the restructuring program. From January&nbsp;2004 through March&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company spent
approximately $258&nbsp;million in capital, including $13&nbsp;million spent in the first quarter of 2007, to
implement the restructuring program. Cumulative annualized cost savings as a result of the
restructuring program were approximately $540&nbsp;million through 2006, and are anticipated to reach
approximately $700&nbsp;million by the end of 2007, all of which are expected to be used in support of
brand-building initiatives. Cost savings as a result of the restructuring program totaled
approximately $75&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2007, resulting in cumulative savings of
approximately $615&nbsp;million to date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Acquisitions and Dispositions:</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">One element of the Company&#146;s growth strategy is to strengthen its brand portfolios and/or expand
its geographic reach through a disciplined program of selective acquisitions and divestitures. The
Company is constantly reviewing potential acquisition candidates and from time to time sells
businesses to accelerate the shift in its portfolio toward businesses &#151; whether global, regional
or local &#151; that offer the Company a sustainable competitive advantage. The impact of any future
acquisition or divestiture could have a material impact on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial
position, results of operations or cash flows, and future sales of businesses could in some cases
result in losses on sale.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the third quarter of 2006, the Company acquired the Spanish and Portuguese operations of
United Biscuits (&#147;UB&#148;), and rights to all Nabisco trademarks in the European Union, Eastern Europe,
the Middle East and Africa, which UB has held since 2000, for a total cost of approximately $1.1
billion. The Spanish and Portuguese operations of UB include its biscuits, dry desserts, canned
meats, tomato and fruit juice businesses as well as seven manufacturing facilities and 1,300
employees. From September&nbsp;2006 to December&nbsp;31, 2006, these businesses contributed net revenues of
approximately $111&nbsp;million. For the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007, these businesses
contributed net revenues of approximately $97&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2007, the Company sold its hot cereal assets and trademarks. The
aggregate proceeds received from this sale were $200&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded a
pre-tax gain of $12&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the first quarter of 2006, the Company sold certain Canadian assets and a small U.S. biscuit
brand, and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of $176&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2005
in recognition of these sales. During the second quarter of 2006, the Company sold its industrial
coconut assets. During the third quarter of 2006 the Company sold its pet snacks brand and assets
and recorded tax expense of $57&nbsp;million related to the sale. In addition, the Company incurred a
pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2006 in recognition of this
sale. During the fourth quarter of 2006, the Company sold its rice brand and assets and a U.S.
coffee plant. The aggregate proceeds received from these sales were $946&nbsp;million, on which the
Company recorded pre-tax gains of $117&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The operating results of the businesses sold, in the aggregate, were not material to the Company&#146;s
consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in any of the periods
presented.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->21<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The following events occurred during the first quarter of 2007 and 2006 that affected the
comparability of statement of earnings amounts:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV align="justify"><I>Income Tax Benefits </I>&#151; In the first quarter of 2006, the United
States Internal Revenue Service concluded its examination of
Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s consolidated tax returns for the years 1996
through 1999 and issued a final Revenue Agents Report on March&nbsp;15,
2006. Consequently, Altria reimbursed the Company in cash for
unrequired federal tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million and pre-tax
interest of $46&nbsp;million ($29&nbsp;million after-tax). The Company also
recognized net state tax reversals of $39&nbsp;million, resulting in a
total net earnings benefit of $405&nbsp;million or $0.24 per diluted
share, in the first quarter of 2006.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV align="justify"><I>Asset impairment, exit and implementation costs </I>&#151; As discussed in
Note 2 to the condensed consolidated financial statements, during
the first quarter of 2007 and 2006, the Company recorded $67
million and $92&nbsp;million of pre-tax exit costs, respectively, and
$110&nbsp;million of pre-tax asset impairment in 2006, on its condensed
consolidated statements of earnings. Additionally, during the
first quarter of 2007 and 2006, the Company recorded pre-tax
implementation costs of $21&nbsp;million and $13&nbsp;million, respectively.
See Note 2. <I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs </I>for
further details of the Company&#146;s restructuring program.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><DIV align="justify"><I>Gains on Sales of Businesses </I>&#151; During the first quarter of 2007,
the Company sold its hot cereal assets and trademarks and recorded
a pre-tax gain of $12&nbsp;million. This gain is included in the
segment operating income of the North America Snacks &#038; Cereals
segment. During the first quarter of 2006, the Company sold
certain Canadian assets and recorded a pre-tax loss of $1&nbsp;million.
This loss is included in the segment operating income of the North
America Grocery segment. In addition, the Company sold a small
U.S. biscuit brand, resulting in a pre-tax loss of $2&nbsp;million.
This loss is included in the segment operating income of the North
America Snacks &#038; Cereals segment.</DIV></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->22<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As discussed in Note 10. <I>Segment Reporting</I>, the Company&#146;s management uses segment operating income
to evaluate segment performance and allocate resources. Operating income for the reportable
segments excludes unallocated general corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles.
Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help investors analyze the
business performance and trends of the various business segments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Consolidated Results of Operations for the Three Months Ended March&nbsp;31, 2007</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The following discussion compares consolidated operating results for the three months ended March
31, 2007 with the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Net revenues increased by $463&nbsp;million (5.7%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($269
million), favorable currency ($172&nbsp;million), the impact of acquisitions ($97&nbsp;million) and higher
pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($18&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of
divestitures ($93&nbsp;million).
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Volume increased 0.9%, due primarily to higher shipments in the European Union and Developing
Markets and, in North America, higher shipments of cheese, biscuits, ready-to-drink beverages and
pizza, partially offset by the impact of divestitures and lower foodservice shipments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Operating income increased by $105&nbsp;million (10.3%), due primarily to lower pre-tax charges for
asset impairment and exit costs ($135&nbsp;million, including the 2006 $13&nbsp;million hot cereal intangible
asset impairment in North America and the $11&nbsp;million intangible asset impairment charge for
biscuits assets in Egypt), favorable volume/mix ($118&nbsp;million), favorable currency ($22&nbsp;million),
the impact of the UB acquisition ($12&nbsp;million) and the 2007 gain on the sale of the hot cereal
brand and assets ($12&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research
costs ($104&nbsp;million), higher costs, net of higher pricing ($45&nbsp;million), the impact of divestitures
($35&nbsp;million) and higher implementation costs related to the restructuring program ($8&nbsp;million).
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Currency movements increased net revenues by $172&nbsp;million and operating income by $22&nbsp;million.
These increases were due primarily to the continuing weakness of the U.S. dollar against the euro.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Interest and other debt expense, net decreased $32&nbsp;million (33.3%), due primarily to $77&nbsp;million of
pre-tax interest income associated with the transfer of tax reserves from the Altria in 2007,
partially offset by $46&nbsp;million of pre-tax interest income associated with the conclusion of a tax
audit at Altria in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company reported an income tax provision of $356&nbsp;million in 2007 and an income tax benefit of
$85&nbsp;million in 2006. The 2006 tax benefit reflects a reimbursement from Altria in cash for
unrequired federal tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million and net state tax reversals of $39&nbsp;million, due to
the conclusion of an audit of Altria Group, Inc.&#146;s consolidated federal income tax returns for the
years 1996 through 1999. Income taxes also include a benefit of $19&nbsp;million in 2007 and $48
million in 2006 from the resolution of outstanding items in the Company&#146;s international operations.
Beginning March&nbsp;31, 2007, Kraft is no longer a member of the Altria consolidated tax return group
and Kraft will file its own federal consolidated income tax return. The Company currently
estimates the annual amount of lost tax benefits to be in the range of $50&nbsp;million to $75&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Net earnings of $702&nbsp;million decreased $304&nbsp;million (30.2%). Diluted EPS from net earnings, which
was $0.43, decreased by 29.5%.
</DIV>

<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U><B>Operating Results by Business Segment</B></U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="justify" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The following discussion compares operating results within each of Kraft&#146;s reportable segments for
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2007 with the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->23<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>
